title: 114_s1885
content: The "Veteran Housing Stability Act of 2015" expands the definition of homeless veterans for benefits under laws administered by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. It also establishes a program for intensive case management interventions for homeless veterans receiving the most healthcare from the Department of Veterans Affairs. The "Veteran Housing Stability Act of 2015" establishes a program for intensive case management interventions for covered veterans enrolled in the homeless registry and annual patient enrollment system of the Department of Veterans Affairs. The program will be carried out at six locations, including cities with the largest homeless veteran populations and suburban or rural settings. The Secretary will select locations with high interaction between the Department and community organizations providing housing and services for veterans. Intensive case management interventions will be provided to at least 20 covered veterans at each location to assist with accessing housing, benefits, and services. The Secretary will select locations with high interaction between the Department and community organizations providing housing and services for veterans. Intensive case management interventions will be provided to improve the stability of their housing and the appropriateness of the health care they receive. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will commence the program of intensive case management interventions by September 1, 2016. A report on the program must be submitted by December 1, 2018, detailing the types and frequencies of interventions, housing status, and employment status of veterans who received the interventions. The program of intensive case management interventions for veterans includes comparing employment status before and after receiving the intervention, utilization of health care services from the Department of Veterans Affairs, costs incurred for such services, and the number of veterans receiving interventions disaggregated by location. The costs incurred by the Department in carrying out the program of intensive case management interventions for veterans, including estimates of costs for health care services to covered veterans without the interventions. Program to improve retention of housing by formerly homeless veterans and veterans at risk of becoming homeless. The Secretary is required to implement a program providing case management services to help formerly homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness retain housing. Grants will be awarded to organizations with a proven ability to offer these services, with priority given to those with experience in transitional housing. The Secretary prioritizes organizations that voluntarily transition from providing transitional housing to permanent housing meeting quality standards. Conversion of facilities funded by grants for housing services is considered compliant with Department needs. The table of sections in chapter 20 of the title is amended by striking section 2013 and inserting new items. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is required to prescribe regulations for a program aimed at improving housing retention for homeless veterans. A report assessing the program's effectiveness in helping veterans retain permanent housing must be submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs by June 1, 2019. The report should include data on the percentage of veterans who received case management services and were able to retain permanent housing by the end of the pilot program. The report on the program for homeless veterans must include data on veterans' housing retention, case management services, use of VA housing assistance, and employment status before and after receiving services. Expansion of housing assistance program for veterans by the Department of Veterans Affairs. The Department of Veterans Affairs is amending Section 2041 of title 38, United States Code to expand housing assistance for veterans, including those in temporary housing and very low-income veteran families. This includes assisting homeless veterans and their families, veterans at risk of homelessness, and very low-income veteran families in acquiring shelter, transitioning to permanent housing, and maintaining occupancy in permanent housing. The Department of Veterans Affairs is amending Section 2041 of title 38, United States Code to expand housing assistance for veterans by providing permanent or transitional housing and referrals for benefits and services. The Department of Veterans Affairs is amending Section 2041 of title 38, United States Code to expand housing assistance for veterans by providing permanent or transitional housing and referrals for benefits and services. Additionally, the table of sections in chapter 20 of the title is being updated to reflect these changes. The Department of Veterans Affairs is expanding housing assistance for homeless veterans, veterans in temporary housing, and very low-income veteran families. They will collaborate with various entities to increase the availability of housing for veterans. Additionally, a National Center on Homelessness Among Veterans will be established. The Department of Veterans Affairs is establishing a National Center on Homelessness Among Veterans to conduct research, assess program effectiveness, and disseminate best practices for addressing veteran homelessness. The Department of Veterans Affairs is establishing a National Center on Homelessness Among Veterans to integrate evidence-based practices, serve as a resource center, and coordinate research and training activities related to veteran homelessness. The Department of Veterans Affairs is establishing a National Center on Homelessness Among Veterans to improve grant and per diem programs. The Department of Veterans Affairs is amending Section 2012 of title 38, United States Code to include a new subsection (e) for reviewing grant recipients and eligible entities' performance in assisting veterans with housing and increasing their income. The Department of Veterans Affairs is amending Section 2012 of title 38, United States Code to include a new subsection (e) for reviewing grant recipients and eligible entities' performance in assisting veterans with housing and increasing their income. Per diem payments will be provided based on performance evaluations and uniform targets will be established nationwide.
